steps.title: Vacuum the furniture with a handheld vacuum.
steps.content: Vacuum the furniture with a handheld vacuum. Run the vacuum over the furniture to pick up as much hair as you can. If you don't have a handheld vacuum, you can use your regular vacuum's hose attachment to pick up hair. [1] X Research source Go forward and back over the furniture in rows so you don't miss any hair.

steps.title: Run a squeegee over microfiber furniture.
steps.content: Run a squeegee over microfiber furniture . Grab a clean, dry squeegee, the kind you use to dry off windows when washing them. Place the rubber edge on the couch, and gently scoot it across the fabric. The rubber will collect the hair on the couch, making it easy to pick up. [2] X Research source Run a vacuum over it when you're done with the squeegee for easy cleanup. This will also work on carpet. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe down most fabric furniture with a damp rubber glove.
steps.content: Wipe down most fabric furniture with a damp rubber glove. Put on a fresh rubber glove, the kind you use for household cleaning. Run it under the faucet and then shake off the excess water. Rub the glove lightly over the fabric, and it will easily pick up pet hair. [4] X Research source If the glove gets clogged with hair, run it under water to clean it and begin again. You can also use a spray bottle to lightly spritz the glove.

steps.title: Rub a dryer sheet over hard furniture.
steps.content: Rub a dryer sheet over hard furniture. Wood, plastic, and laminate can also pick up cat hair. While this is easier to clean up than fabric, pet hair can still cling to the surface. Wipe down the furniture with a clean dryer sheet from your laundry room, which will make picking up pet hair a breeze. [5] X Research source The dryer sheet has enough fabric softener in it that it will grab the hair. Plus, it will make your room smell fresh.

steps.title: Spritz a soft cloth with furniture polish for wooden furniture.
steps.content: Spritz a soft cloth with furniture polish for wooden furniture. Grab a non-abrasive rag, such as a microfiber cloth. Hold it in your hand and lightly spray it with furniture polish. Run the polish over the wooden furniture to quickly pick up pet hair. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Use a dry sponge to wipe pet hair off of curtains.
steps.content: Use a dry sponge to wipe pet hair off of curtains. Run the sponge down the curtain to gather up the hair. You may need to place a hand behind the curtain to hold it in place against the sponge. Collect the hair with your fingers to toss in the trash and pull any excess hair off the sponge to use again. [7] X Research source Alternatively, vacuum the hair off the bottom of the curtain with a hose or hand vacuum.

steps.title: Rub a pumice stone over small areas of carpet.
steps.content: Rub a pumice stone over small areas of carpet. If you have stubborn hair on your carpet, grab a (clean) pumice stone from the bathroom. Run it back and forth over the area a few times, and it will gather the pet hair up enough that you can just pick it up. [8] X Research source This works especially well on stairs.

steps.title: Mist the carpet with a fabric softener and water solution to loosen the hair.
steps.content: Mist the carpet with a fabric softener and water solution to loosen the hair. Mix 3 parts water with 1 part fabric softener and pour it into a small spray bottle. Spray the mixture over the carpeted area until it's slightly damp. Allow 30 minutes for the area to dry, then run a vacuum cleaner over the carpet to pick up the hair. [9] X Research source The fabric softener helps release the pet hair from the carpet. This spray will also work on furniture, but test it in an inconspicuous area first.

steps.title: Vacuum up the rest of the hair on carpet.
steps.content: Vacuum up the rest of the hair on carpet. Once you've removed as much hair as you can, pull out your vacuum cleaner. Run it over your carpet to get up as much of the loose hair left behind as you can. [10] X Research source For stairs, use a handheld vacuum or a hose attachment.

steps.title: Run a microfiber mop over hardwood floors to pick up loose hair.
steps.content: Run a microfiber mop over hardwood floors to pick up loose hair. Sweep up and down the room to quickly pick up the loose cat hair on the floor. Gather the hair in one spot, and then pick it up with a dustpan. [11] X Research source Avoid vacuuming the hair on hardwood floors, as that tends to blow it around rather than pick it up.

steps.title: Set a lint roller by the door for a quick once-over before you leave.
steps.content: Set a lint roller by the door for a quick once-over before you leave. Run the lint roller up and down your clothes to remove hair from your clothes. [12] X Expert Source Safir Ali Professional Dry Cleaner Expert Interview. 15 September 2020. Don't forget to hit your backside, particularly your buttocks, as you can pick up hair from sitting on furniture. Also, go up and down your legs. [13] X Research source You can use a sticky lint roller. With this kind, you run the sticky side over your clothes, then peel off the top layer so that it's sticky again. You can also use reusable lint removers, such as the sticky variety, which you rinse off between uses. Another reusable kind has fibers going one direction that pick up pet hair; the pet hair comes off in an included holder.

steps.title: Run a piece of tape over your clothes if you don't have a lint remover.
steps.content: Run a piece of tape over your clothes if you don't have a lint remover. Wrap the tape around your hand with the sticky side out, letting it overlap itself. Then, rub the sticky part over your clothes to remove excess pet hair. [14] X Expert Source Safir Ali Professional Dry Cleaner Expert Interview. 15 September 2020. If you're having trouble rubbing the tape on your clothes, pat it on them instead. [15] X Research source If the tape loses its stickiness, replace it with a new piece.

steps.title: Dry hair-covered clothes before you wash them.
steps.content: Dry hair-covered clothes before you wash them. Pet hair tends to stick to clothing even after it's gone through the wash. To help remove it, set your dryer on cool and put your clothes in it for 5-10 minutes. The hair will mostly come off and end up in the lint trap. [16] X Research source Add a dryer sheet to the load to help pull the hair off your clothes. You can also use a dryer ball. Wash your clothes normally after you dry them. Using liquid fabric softener will also help get the hair out. This works on freshly washed clothes that have been covered in pet hair, too. Always remove pet hair from your clothes before washing them. Pet hair can get stuck in your washing machine and then end up sticking to your other clothes. [17] X Expert Source Safir Ali Professional Dry Cleaner Expert Interview. 15 September 2020.
